title: The State v. Wiley James
description: James appeals his conviction for distribution of cocaine base, arguing the trial court failed to instruct the jury on mere presence because evidence was presented that tended to show James was present but did not sell drugs.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        
          The State, Respondent,
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        
          Wiley Post
          James, Appellant.
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
George C. James, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4650
  Submitted January 4, 2010 â€“ Filed February
11, 2010

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Elizabeth A.
          Franklin-Best, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief
          Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley
          W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General A. West Lee, all of Columbia; Solicitor Cecil
          Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: James
  appeals his conviction for distribution of cocaine base, arguing the trial
  court failed to instruct the jury on mere presence because evidence was
  presented that tended to show James was present but did not sell drugs.Â  We
  affirm.
FACTS
On September 14, 2005,
  Officer Beth Foxworth (Foxworth) of the Sumter County police department was
  working undercover near the Clarendon County line in search of persons selling
  crack cocaine.Â  A confidential informant (the CI) accompanied Foxworth in her
  car that day.Â  Wiley Post James (James) was sitting in a yellow and white
  Oldsmobile across the street from where Foxworth's car was parked.Â  Upon
  observing James's car, Foxworth hailed James over to her car.Â  
Foxworth asked James if he
  had "a twenty," to which James responded, "What kind?"Â  At
  that point, the CI said, "powder," referring to powder cocaine, to
  which James responded, "No."Â  Foxworth then asked James if he had
  "twenty hard," referring to crack cocaine, to which James responded,
  "Yes."Â  At that point, Foxworth handed twenty dollars to James and he
  handed her a quantity of crack cocaine.Â  Foxworth testified James was the only
  person around at the scene and that he was the only person who sold her the
  crack cocaine.Â  Foxworth also testified she distinctly remembered a tattoo of a
  little girl's face on the inner left arm of the man who sold her the crack.Â  At
  trial, Foxworth was shown the defendant's left arm and stated it was the same
  tattoo she saw on the day of the transaction.Â  In addition to Foxworth's
  testimony, the jury was shown video tape recordings taken by a camera mounted
  inside Foxworth's patrol car of the alleged transaction.Â  
James was found guilty of
  distributing cocaine base and sentenced to fifteen years imprisonment.Â  This
  appeal followed.
ANALYSIS
James admits he walked over
  to Foxworth's car but denies he distributed crack cocaine to Foxworth.Â  On
  appeal, James argues the trial court erred by not charging mere presence when
  the facts of the case warranted such an instruction.Â  We disagree.
The law to be charged to the
  jury is to be determined by the evidence presented at trial.Â  State v. Lee,
  298 S.C. 362, 364, 380 S.E.2d 834, 835 (1989).Â  The trial court commits
  reversible error when it fails to give a requested charge on an issue raised by
  the indictment and the evidence presented.Â  Id.Â  The defendant is
  entitled to a mere presence charge if the evidence supports it. Â State v.
    Franklin, 299 S.C. 133, 141, 382 S.E.2d 911, 915 (1989). Â The failure to
  charge "mere presence" may constitute reversible error.Â  Lee,
  298 S.C. at 364, 380 S.E.2d at 835.
In State v. Dennis,
  321 S.C. 413, 420, 468 S.E.2d 674, 678 (Ct. App. 1996), this court held:

  'Mere
    presence' is generally applicable in two circumstances.Â  First, in instances
    where there is some doubt over whether a person is guilty of a crime by virtue
    of accomplice liability, the trial court may be required to instruct the jury
    that a person must personally commit the crime or be present at the scene of
    the crime intentionally, or through a common design, aid, abet, or assist in
    the commission of that crime through some overt act.Â  Secondly, mere presence
    is generally an issue where the state attempts to establish the defendant's
    possession of contraband because the defendant is present where the contraband
    is found.Â  In such cases, the trial court may be required to charge the jury
    that the defendant's mere presence near the contraband does not establish
    possession.Â  

(internal
  citations omitted)(internal quotations omitted).
We find neither of the two
  situations described in Dennis is applicable to this case and,
  therefore, the trial court did not err in refusing to charge mere presence.
A charge of mere presence was
  not warranted under an accomplice liability theory for two reasons.Â  First, the
  State's theory of the case did not involve accomplice liability.Â  Foxworth
  maintained James was the only other person in the area at the time she came
  into possession of the crack cocaine.Â  Second, we find James's position that he
  was merely present at the scene of a crime but did not commit the crime
  untenable considering the fact that defense counsel conceded there was no
  evidence that anyone other than James was present at the scene.Â  Therefore,
  because there was no evidence of accomplice liability, a charge of mere
  presence on that basis was not necessary.Â  See State v. Stokes,
  339 S.C. 154, 164, 528 S.E.2d 430, 435 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding where the
  State's view of the evidence was defendant was the only person present and
  committed the crime alone, a charge of mere presence on the basis of accomplice
  liability is unnecessary).
Furthermore, a charge of mere
  presence was also not warranted under a possession theory.Â  "[M]ere
  presence instructions are required where the evidence presented at trial
  reasonably supports the conclusion that the defendant was merely present at the
  scene where drugs were found, but it was questionable whether the defendant had
  a right to exercise dominion and control over them." Â Lee, 298 S.C.
  at 364-65, 380 S.E.2d at 836. Â Â However, "a charge on mere presence is
  necessary only when the state attempts to establish constructive possession of
  contraband." Â State v. Peay, 321 S.C. 405, 411, 468 S.E.2d 669, 673
  (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In this case, the State did not seek to establish that James
  was in possession of cocaine.Â  Therefore, a mere presence charge was not
  necessary.Â  See Dennis, 321 S.C. at 420, 468 S.E.2d at 678
  ("Because the State was not attempting to establish Dennis possessed any
  contraband by virtue of proximity, the second application of 'mere presence'
  was not applicable.").
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the trial
  court's decision is
AFFIRMED.[1]
PIEPER and LOCKEMY, JJ.,
  concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Hernandez
description: Victor M. Sandoval-Hernandez appeals his conviction and sentence for murder, arguing the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the lesser included offense of voluntary manslaughter.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Victor M. S.
          Hernandez, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4651
  Heard February 9, 2010 â€“ Filed February
25, 2010

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for
          Appellant. 
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka,
          and Assistant Attorney General Alphonso Simon, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor
          I. McDuffie Stone, III, of Bluffton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Victor
  M. Sandoval-Hernandez appeals his conviction and sentence for murder, arguing
  the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the lesser included
  offense of voluntary manslaughter.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On January 28,
  2006, Rogelio Garcia hosted an engagement party in honor of a neighbor's son.Â 
  Hernandez and his friends attended the party.Â  After Hernandez tried to kiss a
  woman at the party, Garcia became angry and physically ejected Hernandez from
  his home, grabbing Hernandez by the neck and throwing him toward the porch.Â Â Â  
Hernandez left
  the party and went home.Â  He retrieved his gun, intending to use it against
  Garcia if Garcia "messed with him again."[1]Â  Hernandez returned
  to the party, where he began to drink and enjoy himself again.Â  Another party
  guest, Raul Garcia-Gallegos, characterized Hernandez as "tranquil"
  and "calm" after he returned to the party.Â  Hernandez enjoyed the
  party without incident until one of his friends began fighting with another
  party guest.Â  After assisting in breaking up the fight, Hernandez encountered
  Garcia again.Â  When Garcia insulted him, Hernandez drew his gun and shot
  Garcia.[2]Â 
  Garcia re-entered his home, where he died.Â Â Â  
Hernandez was
  indicted and tried for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission
  of a violent crime.Â  At trial, he requested a jury instruction on voluntary
  manslaughter as a lesser included offense of murder.Â  The trial court denied
  his request, finding the evidence insufficient to support the presence of
  sudden heat of passion and sufficient legal provocation.Â  In so ruling, the
  trial court observed that no testimony indicated a physical confrontation
  occurred between Hernandez and Garcia after Hernandez returned to the party.[3]Â 
  Hernandez was found guilty and sentenced to thirty-five years' imprisonment for
  murder, along with a consecutive five years' imprisonment for possession of a
  firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal
  cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only and is bound by
  the factual findings of the circuit court unless clearly erroneous.  State
    v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).  Generally,
  the trial judge is required to charge only the current and correct law of South
  Carolina.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 665, 594 S.E.2d 462,
  472 (2004).Â  To warrant reversal, a trial judge's refusal to give a requested
  jury charge must be both erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.Â  State
    v. Brown, 362 S.C. 258, 262, 607 S.E.2d 93, 95 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hernandez asserts
  the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the lesser included
  offense of voluntary manslaughter despite the presentation of evidence Garcia
  physically and verbally assaulted Hernandez before Hernandez shot him.Â  We
  disagree.Â  
The evidence
  presented at trial determines the law to be charged to the
  jury.Â  State v. Brown, 362 S.C. 258, 261-62, 607 S.E.2d 93, 95 (Ct.
  App. 2004).Â  "A trial judge is required to charge a
  jury on a lesser included offense if there is evidence from which it could be inferred
  that a defendant committed the lesser offense rather than the greater."Â  State
    v. Drafts, 288 S.C. 30, 32, 340 S.E.2d 784, 785 (1986).Â  In determining
  whether the evidence requires a charge of voluntary manslaughter, the trial
  court views the facts in a light most favorable to the defendant.Â  State v.
    Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 321, 474 S.E.2d 430, 431 (1996).Â  However, "[a]n
  instruction should not be given unless justified by the evidence."Â  State
    v. Moultrie, 273 S.C. 532, 534, 257 S.E.2d 730, 731 (1979).Â  "If a
  jury instruction is provided to the jury that does not fit the facts of the
  case, it may confuse the jury."Â  State v. Blurton, 352 S.C. 203,
  208, 573 S.E.2d 802, 804 (2002).
Voluntary
  manslaughter requires proof of two elements, a sudden heat of passion and
  sufficient legal provocation:Â  

  Voluntary manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human being in
    sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation.Â  Heat of passion
    alone will not suffice to reduce murder to voluntary manslaughter.Â  Both heat
    of passion and sufficient legal provocation must be present at the time of the
    killing.

State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 101, 525 S.E.2d 511, 513
  (2000) (internal citations omitted).

  "The sudden heat of passion, upon sufficient legal
    provocation, which mitigates a felonious killing to manslaughter, while it need
    not dethrone reason entirely, or shut out knowledge and volition, must be such
    as would naturally disturb the sway of reason, and render the mind of an
    ordinary person incapable of cool reflection, and produce what, according to
    human experience, may be called an uncontrollable impulse to do violence."

Id. at 101-02, 525 S.E.2d at 513 (quoting Byrd,
  323 S.C. at 322, 474 S.E.2d at 432).Â  
An overt,
  threatening act or a physical encounter may constitute sufficient legal
  provocation.Â  State v. Gardner, 219 S.C. 97, 105, 64 S.E.2d 130, 134
  (1951).Â  Sufficient legal provocation must include more than "mere
  words" or a display of a willingness to fight without an overt,
  threatening act.Â  State v. Rogers, 320 S.C. 520, 525, 466 S.E.2d 360,
  362-63 (1996); State v. Johnson, 324 S.C. 38, 40-41, 476 S.E.2d 681, 682
  (1996).Â  Neither the exercise of a legal right nor a victim's attempts to
  resist or defend himself from crime constitute sufficient legal provocation.Â  State
    v. Ivey, 325 S.C. 137, 142, 481 S.E.2d 125, 127 (1997); State v. Shuler,
  344 S.C. 604, 632, 545 S.E.2d 805, 819 (2001).Â  
However, even
  when a person's passion is "sufficiently aroused by a legally adequate
  provocation, if at the time of the killing those passions had cooled or a
  sufficiently reasonable time had elapsed so that the passions of the ordinary
  reasonable person would have cooled, the killing would be murder and not
  manslaughter."Â  State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 303, 555 S.E.2d 391,
  395 (2001).Â  Whether an accused cooled off prior to a violent act must be
  determined by a review of all the circumstances surrounding the event and the
  people involved.Â  State v. Norris, 253 S.C. 31, 35, 168 S.E.2d 564, 566
  (1969).Â  
We affirm the
  trial court's decision not to charge the jury on voluntary manslaughter because
  the evidence demonstrated Hernandez cooled off between his ejection from the
  party and the shooting.Â  The sole physical altercation between the accused and
  the victim in this case occurred when Garcia argued with and then physically removed
  Hernandez from Garcia's home.[4]Â 
  Furthermore, evidence demonstrated Hernandez experienced a period of cool
  reflection after he left the party and went home.Â  According to Hernandez's
  statement to police, he took the gun to Garcia's party not to avenge a wrong
  already done to him but in case Garcia insulted him again.Â  Upon returning to
  the party, Hernandez did not seek out Garcia.Â  Instead, he "began to drink
  and have a good time again."Â  This evidence indicates Hernandez shot
  Garcia because Garcia verbally insulted him after he returned to the party and
  not because Garcia threw him out of the party earlier in the evening.Â  
Hernandez argues
  the existence of a single piece of evidence that might conceivably support a
  finding of voluntary manslaughter instead of murder created a question for the
  jury. Â Historically, a question concerning the existence of a cooling-off
  period fell within the province of the jury.Â  State v. Goodson, 140 S.C.
  357, 361, 138 S.E. 816, 817 (1927) ("Whether, under the facts disclosed by
  the uncontradicted testimony as to the defendant's physical, mental, and
  nervous condition, and the testimony tending to show the nature of the
  provocation, etc., a reasonable cooling time had elapsed, that is, time in
  which an ordinary man, in like circumstances, would have cooled, was a question
  of fact for the jury and not one of law to be determined by the court.").Â 
  However, more recent jurisprudence permits the trial court to make that
  determination: 

  While the law has not defined a bright-line rule for what
    constitutes a sufficient time for cooling off, this Court has determined that
    whether the defendant's actions during the intervening time between the
    provocation and the killing indicates the absence of sudden heat of passion is
    an appropriate question for the court.Â  See State v. Walker, 324
    S.C. 257, 261, 478 S.E.2d 280, 281-82 (1996) (finding that the defendant
    demonstrated cool reflection through his actions between the alleged
    provocation and the killing); and State v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 322-23,
    474 S.E.2d 430, 432 (1996) (holding that the defendant's actions between the
    alleged provocation and killing did not support a finding of sudden heat of
    passion).

State v.
  Pittman, 373 S.C. 527,
  575, 647 S.E.2d 144, 169 (2007).Â  According to Hernandez, his presence at the
  "continuous violent drunken party" prevented him from regaining
  control over himself following his ejection.Â  However, evidence indicates
  Hernandez left the party, drove home, and
  retrieved his gun, thereby removing himself from any influence the ongoing
  party might have exerted.Â  Moreover, when Hernandez returned to the party, he
  calmly resumed drinking and enjoying himself. Â Hernandez's intervening actions and demeanor upon
  returning to the party support a finding that he cooled off after being
  ejected.Â  No evidence indicates a second physical confrontation between him and
  Garcia after his return.Â  Consequently, the trial court did not err in
  declining to charge the jury on voluntary manslaughter.Â  
CONCLUSION
We find the trial
  court did not err in refusing to issue a jury instruction on voluntary
  manslaughter.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.Â  
PIEPER and GEATHERS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] Hernandez gave the police a statement in Spanish,
  which the interpreter translated into English.Â  Hernandez stated:Â  

  And
    later we started to drink.Â  And a little more later, [Garcia] came out and he
    was insulting me with words.Â  And later we went to the house, and my brother
    stayed behind sleeping, and we returned to the party.Â  And that is when I took
    the pistol.Â  In case [Garcia] continued insulting me, I was going to shoot at
    him.Â  And later on [Garcia] came out and [Garcia] began to insult me, and that
    is when I shot at him.

Later, Hernandez
  stated, "[I]f I had been about my senses, I would have â€“ I wouldn't [have]
  done it."Â Â  
[2] Garcia's autopsy revealed he was shot four times in
  the torso as he faced the gun.Â  Only one of the bullets caused a fatal
  injury.Â Â Â  
[3] In addressing this issue again during sentencing, the
  trial court stated "there had been a sufficient cooling-off period after
  [Hernandez] was put out of the trailer."Â  
[4] In fact, Hernandez did not report to police that a
  physical altercation took place between him and Garcia at all.
